Totally Accurate Battle Simulator to this day is still the one of the best sandboxes to date.
It's goofy in and endearing way; customisable and perfect to play for a couple hours every now and then. Hell ,pardon my language, I play this game occasionally throughout the year and was shocked to see I accumulated over 70+ hrs on it.
 
I recently played through the entire campaign to attain all achievements and have to say it is far better than I expected even if the individual "Campaigns" such as "Challenge" or "Legacy" really don't feel super different and the levels almost blur together. However if you focus on the levels for individual challenge they are quite fun to play.

For achievement-hunters this game can be quite tedious especially with the "Defeat X campaign without losing once" apart from that its a mediocre challenge and Ok in terms of enjoyment in my personal opinion.

However, if you want to get this game I highly advocate you get if for the sandbox and the workshop community levels are the most fun in this game which goes to show how great this game is. 

Overall, I truly suggest you get this game if you have the money to spare I would say it is worth it.

Dear Landfall, 
            I LOVE IT. When i got this like 2020 i think, i was really excited and I was really ENTERTAINED. Most of the time i would sit on my chair getting ready to play and stuff like that, just like the battles and campaigns. As more updates would get in the tabs feature slot I was really REALLY EXCITED and happy. Then when the custom unit creator came in I had no words i don't even know what to say when this day came . All i know was I was going to play this game A LOT more than I usually would. Few months and weeks the neon update came. I was joyful and happy even though it was the last content update Tabs would have, still i was satisfied to participate on this journey and play it. Anyways Landfall, You are GREAT and i also love the other games like Content Warning, Stick Fight: the game, and other games you have made. 
               SIncerely, A fan.

It is a pretty fun game! Getting every secret unit was awesome. Although I did not go through the campaign my self, I know its pretty challenging but fun. And finding each secret unit (trying to do it without tutorials) was difficult but also fun. Oh yeah, two secret maps for people to find in a location that was a mystery for years!

The game sure, no longer will really get updates. However, it is still really fun! I loved to make two different armies of different factions fight each other in sandbox mode. It was amazing. 

There are things like "R2rodman" things, I am not sure how to say it. But these things let you mod this game! Modding this game is insanely fun. One mod gave me even more hidden/secret units to find! 

Overall, it is a really cool and fun game. I suggest that lots of people should try it in their free time.

Straight off the bat: It's GREAT.
I love that you can control units yourself in first person, and the unit creator feature.
There are tons of great mods for the game and it has NO IN-GAME PURCHASES, so no
pay-to-win junk. The graphics are good too.
Friendless? No problem! It's a simulator, so just plop the wobblers down and watch 'em
ruthlessly murder each other :) You don't need another person to do that!
Also, it's not that serious or hardcore. There are no levels, so you don't have to play for
hours every day to keep up with your friends. (If you have them. Just sayin')
Overall a solid game. BUY THIS.

This is not a game you take seriously. You place a bunch of units however you want on two separate teams and watch them fight. There exists a campaign function, but otherwise, this is just a video game fight club.

If the stock units aren't to your liking, you can make or download your own from the game's built-in workshop, along with custom maps. 

If you have time to burn and love watching ragdolls fight with ragdoll physics, I would highly recommend this game.

It's okay.  I wish there was a neutral review. I would recommend it more than not recommend it. There just isn't a lot to do. You place units on the map and they fight, There is a campaign that adds some challenge which basically means defeat these pre-placed units with a set budget. Certain units cost a certain amount so the only real strategy is where you place your units and unit selection. You cannot command or control them after the game starts. The game doesn't take itself serious, it will provide you with several hours of goofy entertainment. This is not something you ever need to play but you won't hate yourself if you buy this on sale.
It is a fun concept. And while I do not see myself playing it a lot. It is worth to have in your library for those days where you just want to orchestrate some crazy battles.

I have followed this game since close to its inception, or, in the very least, during the Open Alpha period. Back then, I merely would watch other YouTubers play it, laughing at its hilarious gameplay and wishing I could play the Closed Alpha that only a few well-known names received. And also, watching a lot of the click bait garbage YouTubers put out at every piece of footage the developers released before clicking off the video once they started playing the actual game.
Then, come April 2019, and the game comes out in Early Access. I was fresh into high school then, but every day, I would come back from school, boot up my computer, and play some TABS. Every day following the first week of a major update was bliss, preceding every day fantasising about the next update until it came out.
I was an extremely active community member, talking and trying to socialise in the TABS space while having diagnosed ADHD and Autism, knowing technically that I had those conditions, but not understanding how they affected me.
When this game came into Full Release, I stayed up all night for it, as the developers were hosting a livestream that would require me to stay up until way past my bedtime.
Hard to believe that was over 3 years ago now. Since then, I’ve adjusted myself socially, made solid friends, and in general am much happier than when I was a super fan of this game. And playing it again, actually playing it, even though I’ve been on it on and off in those 3 years, is still as fun as when I first booted it up back in April Fools, 2019.
But, you probably want to hear about the game, right? So, let’s get into that.

Totally Accurate Battle Simulator is, as you might imagine, a battle simulator. The basic premise of the game has you with two opposing sides, red and blue, and a selection of units ranging from a literal hobbit to an actual military tank used for war and YouTube videos. These units have a cost, which is based on their individual quality and power, and this dictates how fair opposing armies will be. Of course, there’s a catch: each unit is a fully animated ragdoll, and each movement, attack, and inevitable tumble onto the ground is simulated in all its polygonal glory. As such, battles can range wildly in results, with units potentially being capable of killing 5 of themselves, to incompetency so fascinating the Soviets would be jealous.
There’s a sandbox mode, where you get unlimited funds to do whatever you want, but if you want the true TABS experience, you’ll go to the campaigns.

There’s the Introduction (an introduction to the first five factions of the game), the Adventure (random fun levels that usually follow silly ideas for battles), and the Challenge (featuring genuinely tough battles that test your skills and abilities as a commander). Aside from that, you will also notice various campaigns named after seemingly random things. Dynasty? Renaissance? SPOOKY?

I mentioned factions. This is how all the units are sorted; each one is placed into a set of seven, which all follow a certain aesthetic related to a historical period… for the most part.
There are two expectations to the set of seven: Legacy, and Secret. The Legacy faction is an assortment of units that were either present in the previous versions of the game - including the Peasant, Super Peasant, or (hehe), Dark Peasant - or scrapped from initial development despite being mostly complete - including the Wizard, Blowdarter, and the Tank. Yes, Tank. The Secret faction, on the other hand, is always associated with one of the main factions, however, they are not included in those main seven, whether it’s because they’re too unbalanced or simply didn’t fit.

Here’s where another aspect of the game comes in: Secrets. All of the secret units have to be unlocked, and this is done through actually looking through the games maps (each tied to a faction), and finding the unit’s weapons/tools/corpses/other. This applies to the Legacy faction, with the caveat that all those units are confined into the Legacy map (itself a callback to the first version of TABS). Go find all them, but remember, some of them are HIDDEN, so look thoroughly in every single hole you can find (in the game…).

That brings me to another aspect of the game; unit possession. Press F, and you can actually take control of one of these wacky-wavy-arm-flailing-wobbly-motherfuckers. Some of their unique behaviour may be cut off, however, for the most part, you can win battles this way just by bypassing some of the more egregiously idiotic byproducts of their behaviour. It also might help you get an understanding of why some units run straight into the jaws of a fire-breathing dragon parade.

Finally, I come to the life support of this game; community content. Not only can you create your own battles, campaigns, units, and maps, but you can also publish them for the rest of the TABS community to see, as well as play their own stuff! Most of its utter dogass, but there is some genuinely good stuff buried in there.
Not even getting into the growing modding scene. Now that TABS is out, modders have been able to cook up some actually good stuff, rivalling the vanilla game in quality. It’s actually amazing how much customisation there is to the game now, given there was quite literally none back in Early Access (they didn’t even tell you how many units you’d placed!).

So, that’s the broad strokes of what’s waiting for you on the other side of the store page. I can’t recommend this game enough; it’s just plain fun, and it’s unreal how funny the game can actually be while you’re playing it. If this doesn’t convince you, and you’ve read all the way up to here, well, thank you, but also, just buy the game. It’s not expensive, it’s quite literally a steal for what you can get out of it, just go and buy the game!

This review has been rewritten multiple times since I wrote it, mainly because I tried to be funny, and then cringed reading it after the fact. So, I’ve just written a straightforward, no-bullshit encapsulation of what you can do in Totally Accurate Battle Simulator. Thank you for reading, and I hope you buy the game, have fun, and maybe meet someone through the game and get some awesome sex through it. Only if you’re both 18 though. Don’t be a creep.

I asked ChatGPT:” What does TABS stands for?”
He answered me:
“Turtles Always Breakdance Silly”
Funny right? No? Oh ok… anyways, the game is. Its physics are awesome and make me laugh with my friend during boring classes, like math. The campaigns are consistent and engaging, they make you think “What would Sun Tzu do?” or “What if I place 3 Dragons?” Both of these work. One of the things that my friend and I thought very entertaining is the troops creator. Many legends from the Television and  Game industry were brought into TABS by me and my friend, some examples: Billy Butcher, Big Boss, Heisenbones and Jesus Christ. You may see that I don’t have many hours, because most of them are on my friend’s PC, where all custom units and foolish strategies are created. Like the “Goblin” one, which consists of distraction halflings, the enemy troops will kill them first while other stronger thuggish units kill them uncontested. You may ask me “Isn’t creating your own units OP?” Yes, it is. Epic battles such as Saruman the Stinky vs Gandalf the Fool, or A-Train vs Omelandah, or even better, Jesus Christ himself against all the units of the game (it was the only battle which he lost). Definitely worth installing, easy to run even in my shitty PC (those who read my Deep Rock review already know that). 10/10

TABS is a generally just a good game but it gets boring too fast sometimes. Due to the game's limited options for custom content creation and constantly having to resort to 3rd party websites to download mods and to waste time to download mods that don't even work. This game is a good game but like I said, due to the limited amount of features in the games custom content creation, it makes it hard for me to enjoy it. The game vanilla by itself in my opinion, can get boring pretty fast and I don't like that. But despite this, I want to do this game justice and recommend this in my review because if I give it a down vote just for limited content creation, it just feels wrong. I do recommend this game if you are crazy for battle simulators and stuff, of course it's not for everyone but if you give it some time, it can be pretty fun! If you haven't already, I suggest trying it out.

I can already remember my first game of Tabs, my simple red clubber, failing miserably against the club of the enemy, my shield bearer losing to a spike, and me meta-gaming with my trusty mammoth.
There are 4 main parts of Tabs, Units, Maps, Campaigns, and Custom Content.

UNITS:
Tabs hosts a wide variety of units, from snake shooting archers, to holy elephants to flying Valkyries. Because of this, there is no shortage of battles you can create.

9/10

MAPS:
Maps are less plentiful in Tabs, and I feel like a few more general ones would be good. Most of the maps are faction specific, and if you like building large scale battles, you can run into a shortage of maps. However, the details carefully crafted into every map makes them more then worth it.

7.9/10

CAMPAIGNS:
The campaigns are quite short, and sometime lackluster. Although I enjoyed the length of "The Adventure" and, "The Challenge" I feel that a mix of those two could be amazing.

6/10

CUSTOM CONTENT:
The main reason why I love Tabs is the Unit Creators part clipping mechanic allows for incredible units to be created, I've created the avengers multiple times, and countless over units. I won't take a point off for this, but horse, cannon, ice giant, and Minotaur, bases would be greatly appreciated.

10/10

SUMMARY: All and all, Tabs is an incredible game, and I'll put here what I put here before:

A game with a pretty straight forward premise, place down different unit types to defeat  the enemy side. This game is functionally a puzzle game that really had me wanting to complete it. There are two features that stood out to me that made this game fun. firstly was the ability to take control of a single unit during a battle which made for some tense moments and close calls. Lastly was the secrets you can unlock new units and campaigns by exploring each map. This game honestly had me carefully scanning over the many beautiful maps it has. So if you are looking for a fun, not serious puzzle game involving whimsical wobbly warriors wildly wracking at each other, give this game a try.

Totally Accurate Battle Simulator: A Delightfully Wobbly Warzone

If you've ever wondered what would happen if a battle simulator completely ignored the laws of physics, then look no further than Totally Accurate Battle Simulator (TABS). This game is a beautifully chaotic mess, where strategy takes a backseat to hilariously unpredictable mayhem.

What’s It About? TABS lets you pit all manner of units against each other in ridiculous battles. Want to see a bunch of medieval knights face off against an army of angry chickens? Or maybe have Zeus throw lightning bolts at a gang of cavemen? TABS has you covered. The real challenge isn’t winning—it's holding back your laughter as your army flops around the battlefield like they’ve all had a bit too much to drink.

Gameplay: Don’t expect deep tactical gameplay here. You set up your units, hit start, and watch as they stumble, trip, and accidentally take each other out in the most absurd ways possible. But that’s the charm! It’s all about the unexpected. Sometimes your most reliable unit will trip over their own weapon, and other times a random spear throw will change the tide of battle.

Visuals & Sound: The graphics are simple but full of character. The googly-eyed warriors and their exaggerated movements make every battle look like a comedy sketch. The sound design adds to the humor, with each whack, thud, and squawk perfectly timed to make you giggle.

Customization: The sandbox mode is where the real fun begins. Create your own battles, throw logic out the window, and let your imagination run wild. Want to see 50 ninjas take on a giant? Or maybe an army of peasants against a single, overpowered unit? The possibilities are endless, and so are the laughs.
A lot of fun. Especially with the unit creator.

My oh my, where do I even begin... Totally Accurate Battle Simulator is, as the name suggests a Totally Accurate Simulation of a battlefield.. I know this is as somebody with no prior battle experience, which should go to show just how accurate it is. the amount of joy i have derived from this simply beautiful game is nothing to be understated... it is an absolute masterclass that every other game can draw inspiration from in hopes of achieving a fraction of it's glory. Don't even get me started on the gameplay. When deciding where to place your units, it brings upon you a feeling which is a unique mix of fun and stress. To reiterate, THIS is how you make a game... THIS is how you captivate players, and THIS is why Totally Accurate Battle Simulator is the greatest game ever created.

"Totally Accurate Battle Simulator" (TABS)—truly the magnum opus of realistic combat simulations. If you’ve ever dreamed of experiencing the raw intensity of battle with an unparalleled level of graphical fidelity and accuracy, then brace yourself. This game is about to redefine your entire understanding of realism.

TABS has set a new standard by delivering visuals that are so impressively rudimentary, they could have been produced on a 1990s calculator. The characters are a masterclass in blocky, wobbling perfection. Those limbs flailing in every direction? That’s not a bug; it’s a groundbreaking new form of realism.

10/10 Can't stop Playing!

Why Totally Accurate Battle Simulator is the Absolute Worst Game Ever Created

If you've ever been unfortunate enough to stumble upon Totally Accurate Battle Simulator (TABS), then congratulations—your sense of what constitutes a "good" game has likely been tested to its limits. Marketed as a wacky, physics-based strategy game, TABS has garnered a niche following, but let’s be honest: this game is a prime example of how not to make a video game. Here’s why Totally Accurate Battle Simulator is, without a doubt, the worst game ever to exist.

1. Gameplay: A Fiasco of Epic Proportions
Let’s start with the so-called "gameplay." In TABS, you’re presented with a virtual battlefield where you can pit various units against each other. Sounds intriguing, right? Well, it would be if the gameplay wasn’t a chaotic mess. The controls are as intuitive as a brick, and the physics engine is a slapstick nightmare. Units behave erratically—marching off in random directions, flailing their limbs like they’re having a seizure, and generally doing everything except what you want them to do.

There’s a distinct lack of strategic depth, which is supposedly the game's main selling point. Instead of thoughtful planning and tactical deployment, you’re left with a random assortment of units that perform like they’ve been animated by someone with a severe case of vertigo. The entire experience feels like an experiment gone awry, with a dash of slapstick humor that wears thin faster than you can say “what am I doing with my life?”

2. Graphics: A Throwback to the Dark Ages
Now let’s talk about the visuals. The graphics in TABS are reminiscent of a late-90s web game—painfully blocky, garishly colorful, and devoid of any real detail. It’s as if someone decided that the best way to make a game look “quirky” was to make it look like it was designed by a toddler with a crayon. The result? An eyesore of epic proportions.

You’d think that a game with such simplistic graphics would at least have decent performance, but no. The game struggles with its own inept physics engine, causing graphical glitches that can only be described as “comically awful.” Characters jitter around the screen, objects clip through each other, and the whole visual experience is as disorienting as it is visually unappealing.

3. Sound Design: An Auditory Assault
If you somehow manage to endure the game's visual torment, the sound design will gladly take over where the graphics leave off. TABS features an assortment of sound effects that are either painfully repetitive or utterly nonsensical. The sound of units flailing about and the bizarre, looped audio effects create a cacophony that will make you want to slam your head against your keyboard just to make it stop.

The background music is no better—an insipid, repetitive loop that sounds like it was composed during a caffeine withdrawal. It’s as if the creators thought that an incessantly annoying soundtrack would somehow enhance the comedic value of the game. Instead, it just grates on your nerves and adds to the overall misery of playing this travesty of a game.

4. User Experience: A Cluster of Disjointed Design
The user interface in Totally Accurate Battle Simulator is a lesson in how not to design a game menu. It’s clunky, unintuitive, and about as helpful as a screen door on a submarine. Navigating through the various options is akin to trying to find your way out of a maze designed by an insomniac with no sense of direction. The interface is riddled with bugs and inconsistencies, making it a chore just to set up a battle.

Adding insult to injury is the game’s lack of coherent instructions or tutorials. You’re left to flounder about, trying to figure out how to make sense of the chaotic mess on your screen. The supposed “fun” of discovering the game’s mechanics is quickly overshadowed by the frustration of dealing with an interface that seems determined to make your life as difficult as possible.

5. Longevity: A Black Hole of Repetitiveness
If you somehow manage to drag yourself through the initial nightmare of TABS, you’ll quickly discover that the game’s longevity is as short-lived as a mayfly’s lifespan. The core gameplay loop offers about as much variety as a stale piece of bread. The so-called “campaign” is nothing more than a series of repetitive battles that quickly become monotonous.

The so-called “creative mode,” which allows players to build their own battles, is only marginally better. While the ability to customize battles might sound enticing, it quickly becomes apparent that the tools provided are as clunky and frustrating as the rest of the game. The end result is a repetitive and uninspired experience that offers little to no replay value.

6. Community and Support: A Non-Issue
Despite its many flaws, one might expect some form of community support or developer engagement. Unfortunately, Totally Accurate Battle Simulator doesn’t even have that to redeem it. The game’s community, while small, seems to revel in the game’s flaws, which only reinforces the idea that TABS is more of a curiosity than a legitimate gaming experience. Developer support is minimal, and any updates or patches are often more of a band-aid than a solution.

Conclusion: A Masterclass in Gaming Missteps
In conclusion, Totally Accurate Battle Simulator is a masterclass in how to fail spectacularly at virtually every aspect of game design. From its chaotic and erratic gameplay to its abysmal graphics, irritating sound design, and disjointed user experience, the game is a shining example of how not to make a video game. Its lack of depth, repetitive content, and overall poor execution make it a contender for the worst game ever created.

While some may find a perverse kind of enjoyment in its sheer absurdity, it’s hard to imagine anyone deriving genuine satisfaction from this disaster of a game. If you’re looking for an enjoyable, well-crafted gaming experience, Totally Accurate Battle Simulator is a game you should avoid at all costs. It’s a spectacular train wreck that serves as a stark reminder of what happens when a game fails to deliver on virtually every front.

Arguably the game that popularized the battle sim game genre, TABS is a game that is a mix of goofy fun sandbox combat with strategy and tactics. The game has several factions, each with its own unique gimmicks to add to the battlefield and all units come with set points to also add resource management into the mix. The single player campaign is very solid, taking you through very well designed maps each controlling a single faction at a time. 

Outside of the campaign there is a custom battle option to mess around with in your own time, multiplayer to face off against friends or strangers online, a unit creator for others to create their own units and maps to share with others online via the workshop and a hidden set of units not included in the campaign that can be unlocked through finding secrets on the maps. Overall, very very fun to play. 

Pros:
✅ Hilarious ragdoll physics and chaotic battles
✅ Huge variety of units, including secret and custom ones
✅ Tons of replayability with campaign, sandbox, and unit creator
✅ Great for both casual and creative players

Cons:
❌ Battles can sometimes feel more random than strategic
❌ AI can be a little dumb at times
❌ Performance can dip in massive battles

This is a great game! It’s one of those games that’s highly replayable, as much as your imagination allows. It offers endless possibilities and is truly a gem. Even if you’re not just playing around in the sandbox, the campaign provides plenty of content with significant replay value, especially if you’re aiming for achievements related to the campaign, which are really good levels carefully crafted.

That being said, if you’re looking for a deep story, this might not be the game for you. It’s more of a sandbox experience with custom campaigns to explore. Fortunately, the Steam Workshop has a lot of content that enhances the game.

Overall, if you enjoy sandbox games, I’d highly recommend it!

This game is way more fun than I thought it’d be. 

What I thought I was getting was some stupid battle sim, and boy was I right. What I wasn’t right about is the depth of it. 

You actually place troops, can control them in first person, and there’s tons of troop types to choose from and I’m still unlocking more. If you control in first person you can find secrets on the map. 

All in all, it’s a fun, funny, battle sim that’s great for unwinding and isn’t stressful.

Actually fun and strategic game, not just "haha funny characters fight!". The campaign is well made, takes you through different time eras while testing your inner strategist, requiring you to figure out which units to deploy from your arsenal.

Every unit is different, there's so many of them and they're all fun to watch. Do you deploy many cheap melee fighters, or a couple strong mages? Maybe some ranged units behind shields? Hugeass cannon? Do you do a concentrated push, or scatter your units? Most of the time, you'll be combining to get the perfect counterattack to the enemy army, but what's fun is that you can try as many times as you want until it's just right. And you can always take control of one unit, so you can tug the outcome a little.

 Developers need to rework the internals because it shouldn't require such heavy resources just to simulate at 4 FPS. Other wise its fun, just don't try to use it to its actual potential, it'll never run, treat it like a NT Switch Game and give your Rig fan a break.

I want to just get a very important warning out that ONLY campaign progress is saved via steam cloud. custom units, custom maps are NOT tied to the steam cloud so if you uninstall or transfer the game from one drive to another you WILL lose ALL content you have not uploaded to the workshop or have not backed up. so, in my case I probably lost around 100 custom units, about 20ish maps and just a lot of memories. would love to upvote cause there is so many good things about tabs but the game's lack of coverage with the steam cloud is just a gaping hole for me in how I view the game.

(as a note my reliance on the steam cloud is kind of a bias but it's been a super long time since I worried about uninstalling any game and thinking about a lot of lost progress, take this as you will)

Totally Accurate Battle Simulator is a strategy game in which the outcome of the battles depends upon unit placement and the composition of your (usually budget-capped) army. It markets itself as a 'physics' based game, but 'physics' in this instance denotes flailing, wobbly, rubbery units barely remaining upright as they lurch towards the enemy, seemingly without any knowledge of whom they are or why they are fighting. Watching these battles unfold is oddly reminiscent of my uni days, watching cherished acquaintances going to war over mildly-bruised egos, and remarks about one another's parents, usually with a potent cocktail of cocaethylene working its way through their gizzards.

The campaign has a modicum of strategy to it, but is fairly repetitive and is not the main draw of the game. 
Whether or not you consider playing this game to be a worthwhile experience depends entirely upon your creativity and candour. The unit creator can be quite literally endless fun, or an eternal nightmare. 
Therein lies the problem with sandbox games, they give too much agency to the player. The modern gamer has no real clue of how to entertain themselves. Yes, you can create a stunningly-accurate Wehrmacht Prison Guard, and pitch twenty of them against one hundred farmers on a WW2 style map, but this is not something that everyone is going to find as amusing as myself. 

I encourage you to buy this game, use the unit creator and let your imagination run wild. Are you being bullied at school? Painstakingly recreate all of the bullies, and yourself, giving yourself an M16 and a Void Monarch's claymore and fight back in virtual form! Toxic working environment? Recreate your office and co-workers and have an army of ninjas lacerate them all with shurikens. Crushing on the girl across the street? Practice your pick-up lines through physics-based strategy battles. The potential applications of Totally Accurate Battle Simulator are practically endless, but perhaps this is only true if you have the vision to see things through. And so I simultaneously recommend, and do not recommend this game to you. Only you know whether TABS speaks to your soul.

Totally Accurate Battle Simulator (TABS) is a delightfully chaotic and hilariously entertaining game that takes the battle simulator genre to new heights. With its ragdoll physics, quirky units, and endless customization options, TABS offers an experience that is both unique and endlessly replayable.

Gameplay:
The core of TABS lies in its whimsical and unpredictable battles. You have a wide array of units at your disposal, ranging from medieval knights and archers to more outlandish characters like mammoths and potion throwers. Each unit behaves in a wonderfully erratic manner, thanks to the game's intentionally clumsy physics. Watching your units flail around and interact in unexpected ways is half the fun, making every battle feel fresh and amusing.

Graphics and Sound:
The art style of TABS is simple yet charming. The bright, colorful graphics and exaggerated character designs contribute to the game's lighthearted tone. The sound design complements the visuals perfectly, with comical sound effects and a fittingly whimsical soundtrack.

Customization and Creativity:
One of TABS' standout features is its customization options. The Sandbox mode allows you to create your own battles, experimenting with different unit combinations and settings. The Campaign mode offers a series of challenging scenarios that test your strategic thinking. Additionally, the Workshop integration provides access to a vast array of user-generated content, ensuring that there's always something new to try.

Community and Updates:
The developers, Landfall Games, have done an excellent job of supporting TABS post-launch. Regular updates introduce new units, maps, and features, keeping the game feeling fresh and engaging. The community is active and passionate, constantly sharing new battle ideas and custom content.

Overall:
Totally Accurate Battle Simulator is a must-play for anyone who enjoys strategy games with a twist. Its combination of humor, unpredictability, and creativity makes it a standout title in its genre. Whether you're looking for a game to play casually with friends or a sandbox to unleash your strategic genius, TABS delivers in spades. Highly recommended!

So most things about this game are good/fine, but something not many people talk about is the optimization for this game. Like you have to be joking kidding me right. In any other situation the games perfectly fine but the graphics and things going on in the game should not be causing performance issues.

This game is a prime example of why you should be able to rate more specifically.

The core gameplay is amazing, and while it is frustrating at times it quickly fades seeing your goofy units somehow overcome the greatest enemies. Messing around in the sandbox, unit editor and map creator surely grants another 5+ hours of gameplay.

Thats the good part.

Unfortunately there are mutiple annoying aspects of this game that have since made me stop playing.

For starters, while the map creator and unit editor are fun, they are overly limited, and making anything complex with them is basically just fighting them. And as well, you cant re-create in game units with the unit editor (cant make them ride horses, have them transform to a custom unit, etc) and getting them to behave right is incredibly difficult (if you give them any ranged weapon they will act like a ranged enemy, even if you set them to melee). And same goes for the map editor, you can barely recreate any in-game maps using the provided tools and its annoyingly limited (making giant battlefields, or literally ANY custom architecture is impossible).

And, ontop of that, the vast majority of the workshop items made for the game are dependent apon 3rd party mods, and as someone who wants a game to be good without having to mod it for such it is really annoying.

A positive review for the core gameplay being great, but the replayiblity of this sandbox-simulator ends at a point. Still got 65 hours in, worth the money, 7.3/10

Don't get me wrong I still recommend the game but most of my hours are in the unit editor and testing my units. For me it's more fun to build additional unit types and try to balance them.

The game itself is entirely serviceable and has a lot of potential. More than what the developers even begin to scratch the surface of.

I give my recommendation looking at the product itself, and not the potential of what could have been. There is so much untapped potential compared between what this game actually offers, and what I think a game in the genre of 'spawn units and watch them fight' should offer as a whole. In this game, you only ever pick units and where to spawn them, watch the fight with those starting conditions, and the round is over when one team is wiped out.

It's a serviceable mode, completely valid, easy to understand, and a very straightforward way to experience the fights in game. But in my opinion, the rigid structure can be somewhat limiting.

I think having a mode where you place units in real time and receive coins to spawn additional units over time would add a lot of potential modes, especially when you begin to start having objectives to attack and defend - or even having a sandbox/cheat way of spawning unlimited units continuously would go a long way. 

This game is good but there's a lot of missed opportunity in it's brilliant simplicity. 8/10

I LOVE THIS GAME! I was finding a good ragdoll and sandbox game to play. I regret buying people playground because there was no objective to it. However, in this game, there are campaign levels which I really enjoyed playing. Not only that, but when I completed the levels, I downloaded mods from the Thunderstore. If you don't know or like to install mods from third-party websites, then don't worry because there's also a workshop in the game where players can install other people's creation. I really like how this game allows you to create it's own environment and the units. If you like destruction, this game kinda lacks it but there are wall destruction mods! If you like gore and blood, again, this game lacks it but there's a gore mod! If you like sandbox games, this is a must buy.

Serious review:

[b]Note to keep track of: if the game lags, I recommend you to turn off the shadows in the settings, lower the graphics, and other; just, don't remove the goggly eyes, because that might ruin the game experience[/b]

Totally Accurate Battle Simulator is one of the most chaotic, original and absolutely hilarious battle simulators you could ever have stumbled upon, and that says a ot considering the developers behind this gem, Landfall studios, spent 7.5 YEARS of their time carefully crafting this game. And it paid off too, hell, they're still doing some QoLs and bug patches to this day!

First and foremost: be prepared to handle an unholy amount of bugs and glitches, ragdolls and overall sillyness that it could even come close to Cyberpunk 2077 (though your troops won't fall into the ground, but they'll definitely get on with some crazy shenanigans)

Secondly, as silly as this game can get, it has its fair share of achievements, and oh boy, I'm still struggling to beat some of them to this very day! For example: beat X campaign without losing once, that's just bonkers on so many layers in particular campaigns, like DAMN MAN.

If you want to get the most of it without praying to every religious figure your army will win, feel free to screw around here and there in the sandbox gamemode, the core of the game, without much troubles, as the controls are really easy to learn: pick the troop from the selector and right click to place it down, and left click to delete them*.

Or you could hit up your homie (or a stranger) and play a versus mode together, to see how's the best tactician, become Indiana Jones and find some secret units, maps and campaigns scattered here and there in some maps (not telling you where though) and, hell, become Dr. Frankenstein and create your own unique troops, campaigns, battles, factions, EVEN ENTIRELY NEW MAPS, and roll with it!

The possibilities become endless thanks to the support of dedicated modders.

*There's also WASD to move with the camera and the mouse to look in a different direction, and my personal favorite, F to take possess of one of your troops and be the change you want to see, also you'll need to get used to pressing Tab and Esc if you don't want to change the controls.

If you're going to buy the game, I really hope you're going to have the same amount of fun I had playing it.

-Thomas_The_Trein

P.S.: There's also a free "bug DLC" that you can use to your advantage or just for the laughs

Hello Human, here are some notes about the Totally Accurate Battle Simulator experience:

-Very satisfying physics based combat. You have some agency over the battles via the unit possession system.
- Good amount of singleplayer combat to make strategical stratgies
- Lots of mods, not the most convenient in the world to get but a good amount of them can be downloaded
in game
- Easy to make custom content such as units, maps, campaigns
- Light Melee unit combat can be weird sometimes (units falling over too much or large squads immediately dying 2 seconds into the fight)

A halfling and a king. A David and a Goliath. Totally Accurate Battle Simulator (commonly abbreviated as TABS) is a masterpiece in modern storytelling and game design. Much like the Odyssey before it, TABS encapsulates the spirit of an undying will against the most harrowing odds. The warbling battle cries of your stupid children will ring on deaf ears, useless in the face of a low-poly horse as it mercilessly wobbles over their fresh corpses in a burst of speed. Screams beget screams as you watch the joyful fools gain X's where their bright googly eyes once were. But there is always hope. Unless one of the units gets stuck between some rocks. Then you should just restart.

All units, regardless of species, have the same level of intelligence. Roughly that of a damp rock. This not only symbolizes how both man and beast are equalized in times of war, but how the modern human will see himself as greater than his ancestors, when that is simply not the case. Battle after battle you run through time and space recklessly, seeing the evolution of the rapid improvement in their technology and power. Not intelligence though. Never intelligence. Some become reapers, bringers of death, and others put clams on their head and call themselves clams and throw clams that destroy the reapers relatively easily. A clam and a reaper. A David and a Goliath.

To say more would be to rob you of the virgin experience of playing TABS, so I will leave you with this. A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush, but a crow up your enemy's bush is worth more than two birds in unrelated bushes, I think.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing Totally Accurate Battle Simulator I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son bought this game at his birthday, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. Loaded into the game world and started playing but I was stuck on the legacy campaign. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
Thank you Landfall <3

∞/10

Game will forever be special to me as I've known of this game since it was in its open alpha phase when Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton were still in the game, which was back in elementary school when I was in 5th grade and as of now I am currently a Senior in High School (I feel old when I think back). 

Personal reasons aside now. TABS (short form for Totally Accurate Battle Simulator) is a sandbox battle esc game where you have PLENTY of things you can do. Ranging from doing the basic things such as the several totally accurate battles in the campaigns (see what I did there?) or playing against a buddy in a multiplayer match to see who can beat the others units and leave the other crying in a corner over their loss. OR you can dig further and try to find the secret units hidden around the maps in sandbox mode, create your own custom units to use or upload to the community. OR DIG EVEN FURTHER! and mess with some mods, go crazy with said mods and break the game more than you already can in the vanilla game! OR......... go EVEN FURTHER BEYOND and create some custom campaigns, make your own story, make some lore for your campaign/story, get creative (or don't and be basic). ORRRRRR GO EVEN DEEPER THAN BEFORE! and even create YOUR OWN MAPS! mix it all together and well........... You have a game that has ONE limit, that limit being yourself.

Basically to sum this delightful game up TABS (Totally Accurate Battle Simulator) is a game that has ABSOLUTELY NO LIMITS, YOU make the fun, YOU are the fun (if you do all of what I said). 

FULLY SUMMED UP..................... Totally Accurate Battle Simulator is a ∞/10 game if you play it creatively and a 10/10 if you don't play creatively, so PLEASE do yourself a favour and play this game.

Solid sandbox game. I highly recommend picking this game up. 

I like the variety in different units and themes. Wish there were more maps though but atleast there's a map creator. 

The AI can be a little rough around the edges but that's part of the charm and I'm 99% sure it's intentional. 

The different scenarios you can create leads to hours of fun. I also like the custom unit creator so I can make other custom factions aswell as download ones created by other players. Definitely expands the lifetime of the game if the vanilla experience gets stale. 

My only real gripe is the multiplayer. It functions as intended but I wish there was some sort of toggle to disable the money limit and to enable custom units. Correct me if I'm wrong and just missed it ofc. 

Overall, pretty fun game with alot of stuff to do. I recommend.

TABS is a fun, enjoyable experience, and delivers an interesting battle sim. The graphics are reasonably well balanced; you don't need a 4090 to get good fps. The movement is classic unity, everything looks absolutely drunk, and just great fun. One thing I will say is that you will probably find yourself grinding the campaign until all the actually achievable levels are complete, and then you are just stuck with impossible levels and get bored. No matter though, no shortage of community content and sandbox gameplay.
PROS:
+Cool game idea
+Lots of different troops to experiment with
+Make your own content
+Lots of community content
+Very customisable
+Real themes for characters but with a slight twist
CONS:
+Complete campaign levels quickly
+Some campaign levels are ridiculously and impossibly hard e.g: Fantasy Good, Fantasy Evil, Legacy
+Get bored after campaign finished
OVERALL:
I enjoyed this game and know many others who did as well. Thoroughly recommend.

But I should point out that trying to play it strategically was a bit of a disappointment because AI is as stupid as a potato so half the time I had to take control of certain units by myself. 

There is no tutorial on how are you supposed to know what each unit does to know how to counter them, so at first you will be confused and will be using the "press-all-buttons-to-see-what-each-do" strategy. 

Should you buy it? I don't know, it's goofy for the first hour or two and then gets repetitive and even annoying sometimes because of AI, but for the most part [b]it was indeed fun.[/b]

The game is brilliant, the best strategy game I have played everything is perfect I especially love the unit editor and all my abominations I make with it but there is one thing that's stopping the game from being truly flawless and its the level 'Saving Billy' in the legacy campaign, it is hands down one the most painful frustrating levels from any game and here's why [spoiler] so your fighting the ancient faction and your surrounded reasonably tightly by a Zeus a Minotaur and a couple of snake archers, shield bearers, sarissas and hoplites and your tasked with defending a pharaoh, the issue lies with your objective as the pharaoh will use its special ability which will freeze it but then more then likely the Minotaur will charge over to the pharaoh and kill it with a single hit or a snake will come and kill it, my main issue isn't that its a defend mission my issue is that the unit we are defending has no health and its only worth while ability leaves it vulnerable to basically everything. [/spoiler] I have lost so many defeatless runs to this one level and I will not rest until Landfall removes this level.

September 30th, 1998...
It's a day I'll never forget.
The cop inside me died that day.
And that night, Raccoon City was wiped out. Thanks to the bioweapons created by Umbrella.
Somehow, I made it out. But too many others...weren't so lucky.

I was 'asked' later to join a top-secret government program.
Not that I had a choice.
The training, the punishing missions nearly killed me.
But at least they kept my mind off everything.

If I could just forget what happened that night, the pain—even for a second.
This time, it can be different.

 so, i am here to tell people who already have the game HOW TO HAVE A FREE FOR ALL GAME MODE WITHOUT ANY DOWNLOADS!!! kind of. so you can't necessarily make your own game modes without moding or downloading other mods. now for some one like myself i dont like downloading mods so i will tell you how to do so in VANILLA TABS.

First thing to do is go into the custom content area. once you have done that, create a new unit, or click on an existing unit. when you have made your unit (or clicked on an existing one), go to the first page and click on the unit targeting. make sure it says (closest friend). when that is done, REMEMBER THIS VERY IMPORTANT STEP!!!!! MULTIPLY THE DAMAGE BY 10!!! (just add a zero) "why" you may ask? well, since the unit you are making is going to be fighting units on the same team as it, the damage will be divided by 10. (for friendly fire reasons) so if you multiply it by ten, it cancels the damage reduction. 
now that you have SAVED YOUR NEW UNIT, or saved a new version of an already created one, you can finally play a FREE, FREE FOR ALL VERSION OFF TABS!!!
quick notes:     for some reason if you have two diffrent units (free for all) and you place a group of 5 down and then take your other Free for all unit and place them in another group off five somewhere else. the units in group 1 will work together to take down the units in group 2, same goes for group 2 but reversed. (oh yeah, this also works for "stiffys." so if you place down 20 diffrent FFA units and then place down a Stiffy FFA unit... THEY WILL ALL TARGET THE STIFFY FIRST!!! (the perfect example of racism)

An extremely simple physics based game reminiscent of old flash browser games. There is hardly any strategy. Unit AI is poor. It is supposed to be physics sandbox in big part but the environment is 100% static, there is no destruction whatsoever. Unit prices have very loose connection to their prices. Bugs are common, units can get stuck in terrain or fall through it. Multiplayer is pointless since there is no chat (I do not tolerate that bizarre trend of disallowing players to talk to each other) and bugs mess it up.

I've played since early access, and know a lot about this game, and I think it's finally time for me to right a professional review, so hear you go.

[h1] Concept [/h1]

This game has, in my opinion, one of the [b] BEST [/b] concepts of any game ever made (sandbox-games that is) and here is a general list of all the aspects of this game.

Trademark Landfall-Studios collision system that is really funny and good.

Unit Creator that is REALLY complicated below the surface level of what it can do.

Decent progression system. (if you only play RPG's this is not for you, the progression isn't the main focus)

Battle Creator, and Campaign Creator work really well.

[b] Map Creator [/b] blows this game absolutely out of the park.

Secrets are amazing, [spoiler] they include entire unit factions and maps [/spoiler]


Units are controllable and non-controllable.

So there are my two cents.

I FREAKING love this game.

It all started with me finding it on steam one day after seeing some videos of the game, it was fun messing with the 100+ units and creating my own units. as of now the game has a 97% positive review rate. I will tell you everything this game has to offer for 19 wobbly bucks.

THINGS IN THE GAME.

 It has 100+ units (as said before), a unit creator with a color wheel with a recent neon color and multiple options to create special units, you can make your own battles you can reload to when you want to, you can create campaigns using the battles you made which will equal the creativity, each official map has units that can be found by little objects in the area and to know if it is a secret unit stare at it and wait untill you hear a sound and it starts shaking ( 0.5 second wait), a faction creator where you can place your custom made units into (I have made multiple factions starring soldiers, zombies, more units for the base game, overpowered units, units based off popular anime (Jujutsu Kaisen, Dragon Ball Z and One Punch Man), a map creator to make your own maps, everything here means that this game is yours to edit and create.


The game is also on Nintendo,Xbox,PS5 and PS4 (certain features are absent in some of the devices shown). This is also the only game where you can make a 200 hobbits (halflings) fight a being that erases things out of existence with infinite clones with Hajime Kashimo and a naked wobbler that throws millions of apples onto enemies.

FACTS ABOUT LANDFALL

They have made many games some of you may know, the most recent one is Content Warning, A game where you play as a streamer going to haunted areas to get likes and views. A more older one was the truck game (i forgot the name and im not resetting this entire review to see the name) where you hop on and off trucks to get to the finish line, usually was used in commentary videos.

This is the end of the review, I hope you have enough evidence to buy this beautiful masterpiece.

Key Features:
- Physics-based
- Sandbox
- Battle Simulator

Pros:
- Distinct graphics that captures the feel of the game. Look at those cute and wobbly eyes.
- Physics animations are always a blast to look at, such as the ragdoll animations when an in-game unit gets blown up as an explosive. It could also be the way they just move and attack.
- Highly robust Unit Creator that allows you create your own armies and factions, given thatone has the creative output and mental energy for it.
- Campaign is pretty engaging, despite it not being my type as I prefer to exclusively do Unit Creator and create my own armies and factions. 
- Map Creator, for those willing to spend time to create new battlefields for their units. 

Cons: 
- Relatively beefy system requirements. If you want to simulate big battles without lagging like hell, you're gonna need something like AMD's x3D processors, a lot of RAM, and maybe a good GPU. 
- Unit Creator is a bit limited and janky to those who've mastered it already. Things like mounts will require fiddling with config files. Clothing and armor will overlap each other. Things like that. 
- The typical downsides of a sandbox. Can be repetitive, no goals.

Verdict: Highly Recommended. 

In spite of the cons I've listed above, its very much a well-made battle simulator that knows to not take itself seriously and lends to a lot of zany fun.

This is more of a puzzle game, than a strategy game. If you pick the right kind and number of units, you win. That's really it, in my limited experience. There is something to be said about unit placement, as it can be a bit strategic, but just a touch. It's fun, amusing,  and quirky; its good a what it does. I did enjoy some of the campaigns that offer different and/or increasing challenges. It's not necessarily my kind of game, but I see why it's done so well. It's a casual, fun, and quirky battle sim. That's all it is, but its damn good at it. I would recommend this to anyone looking for a casual and amusing battle sim without intense strategic challenge.

Totally Accurate Battle Simulator is a hilarious and chaotic strategy game where you create absurd battles using a variety of units, all powered by unpredictable ragdoll physics. Whether it's knights, mammoths, or futuristic warriors, every battle unfolds in the most ridiculous way possible!

Gameplay Features
Sandbox Mode – Create your own battles with hundreds of different units.
Campaign Mode – Face off against AI-controlled armies with strategic challenges.
Ragdoll Physics – Watch as your troops hilariously stumble, fall, and clash in unpredictable ways.
Unit Customization – Design your own warriors with unique abilities.
Multiplayer – Battle against other players in online or local matches.
Performance
With your RX 7800XT, Ryzen 7 5700X, and 32GB of RAM, TABS runs at 60+ FPS on max settings, even in large-scale battles with tons of units on screen. The game is well-optimized, ensuring smooth gameplay no matter how ridiculous the battlefield gets.

Conclusion
If you enjoy chaos, creativity, and wacky physics, Totally Accurate Battle Simulator is an absolute blast. Whether you're making an army of chickens or watching samurai battle zombies, there's never a dull moment! 🐔🎯🔥

[b] Totally Accurate Battle Simulator [/b] is a delightful palate cleanser from a gaming world that, let's face it, often takes itself too seriously. The cheeky humor, giant explosions, wacky "squawkcore" sound effects, satisfying slow-motion replays, and zany ragdoll physics flambéed with love into every pixel makes it so stinking hilarious. I'll never stop laughing from watching googly-eyed knights wield swords like a baguette while getting unceremoniously body-slammed by a mammoth or a king unintentionally swan dive into the abyss. 

Despite the craziness, there is an artfulness to TABS’ lunacy. It's a sandbox that feels meticulously designed to foster joy and mayhem in equal measure. The levels are also challenging yet engaging, and trying to find all of the towers is an adventure itself. The world design is wholesome, colorful, and delightful. TABS is a cartoonish slapstick with an unapologetic embrace of chaos that makes it a comedic masterpiece without being crass. It's a game everyone can enjoy, especially if you embrace the whimsical with open arms.

Elden Ring is a breathtaking achievement that sets a new standard for open-world action RPGs. FromSoftware has seamlessly blended the rich, atmospheric storytelling they’re known for with an expansive, interconnected world that feels alive and untamed.

The Lands Between invite endless exploration, rewarding curiosity with stunning vistas, hidden dungeons, and challenging foes. Every corner holds a secret, and the thrill of discovering powerful weapons, unique locations, or a harrowing boss fight never gets old. The world design is both massive and intricate, offering a sense of scale that never feels overwhelming thanks to its careful structure and environmental storytelling.

The combat is signature FromSoftware, refined and brutal, demanding both precision and adaptability. Whether you favor swordplay, sorcery, or something in between, the game encourages experimentation and rewards mastery. The sheer variety of builds and playstyles is staggering, ensuring that no two players will have the same experience.

What truly elevates Elden Ring is its freedom. You're given the reins to forge your own path, whether you charge headfirst into danger or take the time to piece together the game’s cryptic lore. The narrative, co-created by George R.R. Martin, adds a touch of mythic grandeur to the world, creating a sense of history that enriches every step of your journey.

For veterans of FromSoftware’s games, Elden Ring feels like the culmination of everything the studio has learned. For newcomers, it’s an invitation to experience the thrill of perseverance and discovery in a world like no other.

In short, Elden Ring is not just a game—it’s an experience, a testament to the artistry of game design, and a world that will linger in your mind long after you’ve put the controller down.

i don't have much time on this game as of now since i played on my dads computer, but it was so fun i had to get it on my one as well. this game can entertain me for hours on end, i would absolutely recommend it to anyone who shows interest in battle simulators, or just likes messing around with rag doll physics.

you wont be able to create massive battles while maintaining a healthy frame rate without a VERY high end PC, ( which i do not have): ), however the goofiness and individual physicists of each unit more than makes up for it in my opinion. the slow motion feature at the click of your mouse helps a lot with the frame rate though. 
almost all the controls are simple and effective even for a new PC player like myself.
the unit possessing feature is really fun as well and can be used to cheese parts of the campaign if you want.

the campaign and strategy is fun but i almost exclusively use sandbox instead, speaking of which, its great. there's lots of maps to choose from and the battle settings allow for lots of customisation. and the default units are fun to mess around with, but most of them will get a little boring after a while, which brings me on to the best part of the game, the custom content.
the unit creator is single-handedly responsible for almost all my play time. you can create units using assets from the game, including weapons, armour and abilities. you can change the colour of them and change the base stats of the unit from size to voice and then put them all in to your own custom factions, which can be easily toggled on and off when in sandbox. its an easy to use system, however still has a lot of drawbacks that make it feel clunky and tedious to use sometimes. ill list the main ones.
1. its hard to find the specific pieces you want in the sea of assets.
2. the options you have can feel limiting, especially when you already have lots of custom units.
3. its really hard to balance units because you don't know the exact damage of each weapon/ability and its really hard to test without going into sandbox, which is annoying. you have to use a damage multiplier to get the desired output. this effects every thing, (same with the attack speed multiplier), including all the abilities, making it very restricting to choose things you think look cool while also being balanced.
4. you cant use horses or increase weapon size

i probably spent way too long on that but it makes the game for me. there are other things i haven't talked about like the map creator but i haven't used that much so i don't wanna give any amateur bias.
to not leave it on a negative note, ill conclude with its a REALLY fun game and my favourite battle simulator I've played!

If you are playing this game and haven't tried out the custom content, PLEASE do! I've been addicted to this game and have been getting captivated by the clanging of swords and redirection and parrying of projectiles from my modded units. this game is TOTALLY worth the price and is very ACCURATE to a real BATTLE SIMULATION!
